_header: O goodly fair which I most love and dread
_description:
Charles d’Orléans, a roundel translated from his French poem (Champollion-Figeac (1842)
XChampollion-Figeac, Aime. Les Poesies du duc Charles d’Orleans. Paris, 1842, 35) — 14 lines

BodRawK38.Editions:
Hausknecht,  Emil. 
             “Vier gedichte von Charles d’Orleans.” 
             Anglia
         17 (1895): 445-7: 446-7.
Bliss,  Philip. 
             Reliquiae Hearnianae.
         London: J. Russel Smith, 1869: 1.266.

BLHar682.First Lines: Goodly fayre which y most loue and dredeSuch is myn happy suche grace is me ordeynyd…
BLHar682.Last Lines: …That yowre daunger hath me enprisonydLonge in the bewte of yowre goodlihed
BLHar682.Note: Second line mostly erased and replaced in margin by a later hand with “yn soche hape and grace as have y wonyd.” As written, repeats first words of lines 1-2 at end to indicate going back to first four lines of the roundel.
